Research article Construction of visible light-driven ternary S-scheme melamine sponge MS/TpTt/ZIS heterojunction photocatalysts for enhanced photocatalytic pollutant removal and hydrogen evolution Qingmei Tang Writing – original draft Supervision Software Methodology Formal analysis Data curation Conceptualization a Yuqi Wan Supervision Resources Methodology Investigation Formal analysis a b Yuzhuo Wan Methodology Data curation Conceptualization a Zhiquan Pan Validation Supervision Resources Investigation Funding acquisition a Qingrong Cheng Writing – review & editing Supervision Resources Methodology Investigation Funding acquisition Conceptualization a ⁎ a Engineering Research Center of Phosphorous Development and Utilization of Ministry of Education, Wuhan Institute of Technology, Wuhan 430205, PR China Engineering Research Center of Phosphorous Development and Utilization of Ministry of Education Wuhan Institute of Technology Wuhan 430205 PR China Engineering Research Center of Phosphorous Development and Utilization of Ministry of Education, Wuhan Institute of Technology, Wuhan 430205, PR China b The Faculty of Dentistry, The University of Hong Kong, 999077, Hong Kong, China The Faculty of Dentistry The University of Hong Kong 999077 Hong Kong, China The Faculty of Dentistry, The University of Hong Kong, 999077, Hong Kong, China ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract In this study, a novel S-scheme MS/TpTt/ZIS sponge heterojunction was successfully constructed using melamine sponge foam as a carrier. MS/TpTt/ZIS heterojunction can degrade MO solution efficiently, and the biotoxicity of the degraded solution was evaluated by germination and growth of mung bean. Moreover, MS/TpTt/ZIS heterojunction has excellent photocatalytic performance for hydrogen production and CO2 reduction. Furthermore, the TMB oxidation result showed that MS/TpTt/ZIS heterojunction also has a superior molecular oxygen activation ability. Finally, the charge transfer mechanism in the heterojunction revealed by work function calculations, and the reasonable S-scheme charge transfer mechanism was proposed. The superior photocatalytic performance was attributed to S-scheme heterojunction promoting charge separation and transfer efficiency and solid sponge heterojunction enhancing the visible light absorption and utilization. Charge separation critical for improving photocatalytic performance. But single semiconductor cannot realize efficient charge separation and transport. Little research has been reported on using melamine foam (MS) as a carrier. Herein, we have successfully synthesized a heterojunction MS/TpTt/ZnIn2S4-x% (MTZIS-x%) photocatalysis with MS as the carrier by solvothermal method. It was found the degradation rate of MO over MTZIS-3 % could reach almost 100 %, and the biotoxicity tests showed that degraded residual liquid of MO was almost non-biological toxicity. Moreover, the ptotocatalytic H2 evolution rate of MTZIS-3 % reached to 11523.64 µmol g−1h−1, which was 7.02, 11.91 and 13.19 times than that of ZIS, MS/TpTt and COF-TpTt. And the evolution rate of photoreduction CO2 to CO was 501.55 µmol g−1 h−1. The excellent photocatalytic property was owing to the S-scheme band structure facilitated the separation of electron-hole efficiently and retained the highly reducing electrons. This work provided a theoretical reference for the construction of efficient new heterojunction photocatalysts using MS as a carrier. Keywords MS/TpTt/ZIS Biological toxicity Ptotocatalytic H2 evolution Photoreduction CO2 S-scheme Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Photocatalysis can transform solar energy into chemical energy, which has been widely noticed and researched because of its green, clean and high efficiency [1–3]. The strategy effectively addressed the escalating energy crises and environmental pollution issues. [4,5]. It mainly included three processes: light absorption; excitation of photogenerated carrier generation, separation and transfer and surface photocatalytic reaction. Currently, researchers have proposed various methods to utilize solar energy, such as photoelectrolysis (PE), photovoltaics (PV), and photocatalysis (PC) [6–8]. Photocatalytic degradation, hydrogen production and CO2 reduction as a branch of PC field, was the most efficient way to utilize solar energy. However, conventional semiconductors were limited by photogenerated carrier recombination in photocatalytic processes. To solve this problem, many methods have been proposed, such as morphology control, crystal surface modulation, doping, constructing heterojunction and homojunction, defect engineering and piezoelectric field construction [9–14]. Among them, constructing heterojunction is considered to be one of the most efficacious methods to solve the photogenerated carrier composite. Since 1967, TiO2 was found has the photocatalytic property [15], various photocatalysts have been studied and reported. such as metal oxides (Fe2O3, WO3, ZnO, In2O3, etc.) [16–19], metal sulfides (CdS, MoS2 etc) [20,21], Bi-based compounds (BiOX (X = Cl, Br, I), BiVO4, Bi2WO6, Bi2MoO6 etc) [22–25], g-C3N4 [26], elemental semiconductors (red phosphorus and black phosphorus, etc,) [27], metal–organic framework materials (MOFs) [28], conjugated microporous polymers (CMPs) [29], covalent organic framework materials (COFs) [30]. The ternary sulfur-containing compound ZnIn2S4 was an excellent semiconductor photocatalytic material, which was applied to photocatalytic H2 evolution and CO2 reduction due to its negative conduction band position [31]. However, the poor light stability, spontaneous aggregation caused a low surface active sites, these blocked the transfer of photogenerated charge carriers [32]. Currently, many materials, such as BiOBr [32], MoO3-x [33], TiO2-X [34], g-C3N4 [10], ZnSe [35], CuS [36], CuFe2O4 [37] have been successfully constructed heterojunctions with ZnIn2S4 and applied in photocatalysis. The photocatalytic performance was significantly improved in this case. However, there were few reports on the construction of heterojunctions of ZnIn2S4 with COFs to enhance the photocatalytic efficacy. As a “new star” in the field of photocatalysis, COFs have been widely studied. Due to their highly ordered crystallinity, tunable topology, organised pore structure, high specific surface area, high stability have been rapidly developed and applied to various fields, such as lithium batteries, energy storage, catalysis, etc. [38,39]. COFs were porous conjugated polymers formed by linking organic units through covalent bonds, mainly including boron, imine and triazine-based COFs [40]. Among these COFs, nitrogen-rich conjugated triazine backbone COFs with good photoresponse and stability have demonstrated significant promise in photocatalytic decomposition of aqueous hydrogen [41]. Moreover, the structure of triazine unit was electron deficient and could act as electrons acceptor [41]. Irreversible reaction occurring in β-ketoenamine interconversion could induce high chemical stability [42]. Based on these, COFs with β-ketoenamine bonds and triazine structural units were established for efficient photocatalysis. However, because COFs are mostly crystalline powders, they are not easy to be recovered in solution, and the photogeneration carriers are easy to recombine, which limits their application in photocatalytic production. In this work, a triazine-based β-ketenamine COF-TpTt was successfully synthesized. To solve the powder problem of COFs, we used MS as a carrier to synthesize MS/TpTt sponge, and ZnIn2S4 was allowed to construct heterojunction with MS/TpTt by in situ growth to obtain MS/TpTt/ZIS heterojunction. The detailed synthesis path was demonstrated in Scheme 1 . Except for carrier, MS was also a unique source of melamine ligands. Results showed that MS/TpTt/ZIS showed outstanding photocatalytic activity under visible light. Moreover, the mechanism of S-scheme charge transfer provided a strong guarantee for efficient photocatalysis. This work introduced a novel idea for building COFs-based heterostructures. 2 Experimental 2.1 Synthesis of ZnIn2S4 (ZIS) ZnCl2, InCl3·4H2O and C2H5NS (TAA) (0.5:1:2 mmol) were put into 30 mL of aqueous glycerin solution (VH2O:VGly = 4:1). Following 15 min of magnetic stirring, it was continuously heated at 60 ℃ for 2 h, naturally cooled, cleaned using deionized water and anhydrous ethanol for 3 times. Vacuum-dried at 80 ℃ for 12 h to get bright yellow powder. 2.2 Synthesis of MS/TpTt 12 pieces of MS (1 × 1 × 1 cm) and 79 mg of 2,4,6-trihydroxy-1,3,5-benzen tricarbaldehyde (Tp) were put into 25 mL Dimethyl Sulfoxide (DMSO) and dispersed by ultrasound for 10 min, then 45.7 mg melamine (Tt) was put into the mixture. After ultrasonication for 30 min, frozen and degassed several times. Then it was sealed in a 100 mL PTFE-lined high-pressure stainless steel reactor and heated for 24 h at 150 ℃. After natural cooling, ultrasonically cleaned with DMF and anhydrous ethanol for 3 times and dried for 12 h at 80 °C in vacuum to obtain MS/TpTt (COF-TpTt was synthesized without MS) 2.3 Synthesis of MS/TpTt/ZnIn2S4 Some mass of ZnIn2S4 (wt = 1 %, 3 %, 5 %, 8 %, 10 %) was added to the above synthesized MS/TpTt mixture solution, after ultrasonic mixing, moved to a 100 mL PTFE-lined high-pressure stainless steel reactor and warmed for 24 h at 150 ℃. Cooling natural, cleansed ultrasonically using DMF and anhydrous ethanol for 3 times and dried under vacuum for 12 h at 80 ℃ to get MS/TpTt/ZnIn2S4 (abbreviated as MTZIS-x%), and the powder was collected. The detailed synthetic routes were showed in Scheme 1. 2.4 Characterization The characterization approaches were given in supplementary materials. 2.5 Photocatalytic performance evaluation The photocatalytic activity was assessed by degradation of MO under visible light. Before illumination, 10 mg sample was put into 50 mL aqueous MO (30 mg/L) and mixed evenly. Under dark condition, magnetic stirring for 30 min to get adsorption–desorption balance. Then photodegraded and 3 mL mixture was removed at 10 min intervals and filtered via a 0.22 µm organic filter. The MO concentration was recorded at 464 nm by UV–Vis spectrophotometer. Stability of catalysts were studied by recycling the mixture after photocatalytic degradation. The recycled sample was washed with anhydrous ethanol, drying and the next photocatalytic degradation cycle was carried out (the process was repeated five times). 2.6 Photoelectrochemical analysis Standard three-electrode systems with Na2SO4 solution (0.5 M) as electrolyte investigated photoelectrochemical properties of materials. Pt wire, conducting glass (FTO glass) and saturated Ag/AgCl electrode as counter, working and reference electrode. Usually, 20 mg sample was mixed with naphthol (0.2 mL) and isopropanol (4.8 mL) ultrasonic for 30 min. After equally applying 200 µL on the conducting glass. 2.7 Photocatalytic hydrogen evolution The photocatalytic H2 evolution test was done in cylindrical quartz reactor with 150 mL. Light source was a 300 W Xenon lamp. 80 mL deionized water, 30 mg sample and the sacrifice agent (TEOA aqueous solution with 0.5 % Pt) were mixed. After mixing well, nitrogen was used to empty the reactor for 20 min to eliminate the dissolved oxygen. The reactor was kept at normal temperature by circulating water. 300 μL gas was get from the reactor using a needle every hour. The quantity of H2 produced was measured using gas chromatography (Tianmei GC 9200, TCD, N2 as a carrier). The photocatalyst's stability was verified by repeating this process four times. 2.8 Photocatalytic CO2 reduction A 110 mL sealed quartz cylindrical reactor with an irradiation area of 28.12 cm2 was taked to conduct the photocatalytic CO2 reduction reaction. Light source was a 300 W xenon lamp (light intensity 1000 mW/cm2). 20 mg sample was put into 50 mL mixed solution (H2O:MeCN:TEOA = 1:3:1) and dispersed by ultrasonication for 10 min. Then the reactor system was purged with CO2 for at least 20 min to ensure that the air in the reactor was completely replaced by CO2 and that the internal partial pressure was 0.04 MPa. Subsequently, 300 μL of gas was removed from the reactor every hour with a syringe needle and quantified by a gas chromatograph (GC9790II, China). Five times of this process were done to verify the photocatalyst was stable. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization SEM and TEM were taked to analyze the surface morphology and microstructures of samples. ZIS exhibited flower-like morphology consisting of a large number of nanosheets (Fig. 1 a). COF-TpTt showed intertwined fiber structure (Fig. 1b). MS has a large pore structure with an open size of 120 μm, and the surface fibers were smooth (Fig. 1c, d). After loading COF-TpTt, MS retained the original macroporous structure and COF-TpTt grew on the original fibers of MS, and mainly stacked growth in the junction of the original MS fibers (Fig. 1e, f). The large pore structure of MS/TpTt was slightly reduced due to the loading of COF-TpTt. After the addition of ZIS, MS still retained its macroporous structure, and ZIS combined with COF-TpTt to grow on the fibers of MS, forming MS/TpTt/ZIS heterojunction (Fig. 1g, h). Moreover, EDS-mapping images of MS/TpTt/ZIS showed a even distribution of elements C, N, O, S, Zn and In on MS (Fig. 1i–o), and the detailed values were shown in Fig. S1. Fig. 2 a and b were the TEM and HRTEM images of ZIS, the lattice fringes spacing was 0.32 nm corresponded to (102) crystalline plane of ZIS. The TEM image of COF-TpTt was exhibited in Fig. 2c, which was matched with the SEM results. Fig. 2d displaied the TEM image of MS/TpTt, and observed that that COF-TpTt grown on the surface of MS. FT-IR was taked to show the chemical identity for materials. The wide peaks at 3553–3290 cm−1 for all samples were due to the stretching vibrations of –NH2 (Fig. 3 a). The bands at 1615, 1526 and 1230 cm−1 were due to the stretching vibration of −C=O, −C=C and −C-N bonds, separately. The characteristic peaks of MS and COF-TpTt could be observed in MS/TpTt, which initially proved the successful preparation of MS/TpTt. The distinctive peak at 805 cm−1 resulted from stretching vibration of a typical triazine unit. For the FT-IR spectra of ZIS, two characteristic peaks at 1649 and 1010 cm−1 corresponded to the surface adsorded water and –OH, respectively [32]. No characteristic peaks of ZIS in MTZIS-3 % was owing to the low loading content of ZIS in MTZIS. To further determine the presence of ZIS in composite MTZIS, the XRD was used to investigation the crystal structure of the samples. In Fig. 3b, COF-TpTt, MS/TpTt and MTZIS-3 % presented two distinct characteristic peaks at 9.6° and 27.5°, respectively (The figure on the right showed the enlarged XRD patterns of COF-TpTt, MS/TpTt and MTZIS-3 %. Fig. S2 is the XRD pattern of simulated COF-TpTt), which indicating COF-TpTt, MS/TpTt and heterojunction MTZIS-3 % with good crystalline properties. Due to the amorphous structure of MS, the XRD pattern of MS has a weak hump ranging from a 16.9° to 29.8° [43]. Nevertheless, the diffraction peaks of COF-TpTt and MS can be seen in the XRD pattern of MS/TpTt, which further proved COF-TpTt was successfully loaded on MS. As for ZIS, there were two distinct diffraction peaks at 27.6° and 47.5°, consistenting with the (1 0 2) and (1 1 0) crystal planes of ZIS (PDF#65-2023), separately. The two peaks at 27.6° and 47.5° were also clearly observed in heterojunction MTZIS-3 % (The inset showed an enlarged view of diffraction peak at 47.5°), which demonstrated the heterojunction has been successfully constructed between ZIS and MS/TpTt. Fig. 4 displaied the N2 adsorption–desorption isotherms and pore size distributions of ZIS, COF-TpTt, MS/TpTt and MTZIS-3 %, and the associated parameters can be found in Table S1. The samples of ZIS, COF-TpTt, MS/TpTt and MTZIS-3 % showed type IV isotherms with typical H3 hysteresis loops (Fig. 4a–c), suggesting existence mesopores and macropores in the samples [19,44]. The inset of Fig. 4b showed the negative N2 adsorption for MS/TpTt was due to the fact that the pore size of MS was larger than 100 nm, while the N2 adsorption was mainly measured for pore materials within 50 nm. The Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) surface area of ZIS was 123.97 m2/g, it was higher than previously reported [19,45]. The BET surface area of COF-TpTt was 118.47 m2/g. After formation the MS/TpTt, its BET surface area reduced to 1.98 m2/g, which was attributed to the large pore size structure of MS, and also further proved that COF-TpTt was successfully loaded on MS. Compared to MS/TpTt, the BET surface area of MTZIS-3 % (15.89 m2/g) was slightly increase, due to adding ZIS made the pore size of MTZIS was slightly reduced, proved the successful synthesis of the MTZIS. The pore size distributions of ZIS, COF-TpTt and MTZIS-3 % were in the ranges of 0–50, 0–211 and 0–208 nm, respectively (Fig. 4d–f). The average pore sizes of the three were 9.62, 14.86 and 44.43 nm, respectively. The mean pore volumes were 0.31, 0.35 and 0.06 cm3/g, respectively. The pore sizes of MS/TpTt were mainly in the range of 75–150 μm, which was tested by a high-performance fully automated mercuric piezometer (Fig. 4e). The large reduction in both specific surface area and average pore volume of the composite MTZIS was the result of the large pore size of the MS. The optical absorption property of samples were assessed via UV–visible diffuse reflectance spectroscopy (DRS). In Fig. 5 a, the absorption band edge of MS at 300 nm and only has the ability to absorb UV light. ZIS and COF-TpTt showed good visible-light absorption, and the absorption band edges were around 520 and 650 nm. Compared to COF-TpTt, the visible-light absorption capacity of MS/TpTt was significantly increased, suggesting that MS as a carrier was benefit to improve the ability to absorb light. Meanwhile, the absorption band edge of heterojunction MTZIS-3 % exhibited significantly red shift, and the visible light absorption range and intensity higher than all samples. Moreover, Fig. S3 demonstrated that the composite MTZIS-x (x = 3 %–10 %) has the strongest light-absorbing properties when the loading of ZIS was 3 %. It was further indicated that MS/TpTt and ZIS were successfully composited (successful synthesis of composite MTZIS-3 %). Corresponding band gap (Eg) values of ZIS, MS, COF-TpTt and MS/TpTt were calculated to be 2.59, 4.37, 2.72 and 2.65 eV, separately, according to the Kubelka-Munk function (Fig. 5b). Compared with COF-TpTt, the Eg of MS/TpTt was reduced by 0.07 eV. Furthermore, the type of semiconductors and the flat band (Efb) potentials were measured by Mott-Schottky curve (M−S). In Fig. 5c–e, ZIS, COF-TpTt and MS/TpTt were all exhibited positive slopes in M−S plots, suggesting they were all n-type [37]. The Efb values for ZIS, COF-TpTt and MS/TpTt were −1.25, −0.41 and −0.61 V (vs. Ag/AgCl). According to Efb(NHE) = EAg/AgCl + E θ Ag/AgCl (0.197) conversion to the standard hydrogen electrodes were −1.05, −0.21 and −0.41 eV (vs. NHE), separately. For n-type semiconductor, the Fermi energy level (EF) was equal to Efb [46], and the conduction band (ECB) was more negative 0.1 eV than the Efb [10]. Thus, the EF values of ZIS, COF-TpTt and MS/TpTt were −1.05, −0.21 and −0.41 eV (vs. NHE), and the ECB values for ZIS, COF-TpTt and MS/TpTt were −1.15, −0.31 and −0.51 eV (vs. NHE), separately. The valence band (EVB) was calculated following the formula: (1) E VB = E CB + E g Thus, the EVB values for ZIS, COF-TpTt and MS/TpTt were 1.44, 2.41 and 2.14 eV (vs. NHE). Considering the analysis above, the band structures of ZIS, COF-TpTt and MS/TpTt were demonstrated in Fig. 5f. And the clear datas of ZIS, COF-TpTt and MS/TpTt were displayed in Table S2. The chemical valence state and elemental composition of samples were ascertained via XPS. The XPS survey spectra of samples were displayed in Fig. S4. C 1s, N 1s, O 1s, S 2p, In 3d and Zn 2p elements can be detected in heterojunction MTZIS-3 %, the results were consistent with EDS analyses. The peaks intensity of S 2p, In 3d and Zn 2p elements were weak owing to the low ZIS content. The C 1s spectra was shown in Fig. 6 a, for MS and COF-TpTt, there were two and four peaks at 284.8, 286.9 eV and 284.8, 286.0, 287.0, 288.1 eV, which pertain to C=C/C–C, C=N, C–N and C=O bonds, separately. Compared to COF-TpTt, the C-N and C=O bonds of MS/TpTt were shifted to higher binding energy (287.8 and 288.8 eV) and the peaks intensity changed to weaker, indicating a chemical interaction existed between MS and COF-TpTt in MS/TpTt, which was ascribed to β-ketoenamine bonding [43]. The N 1s spectra was shown in Fig. 6b, for MS and COF-TpTt, the two peaks at 400.0, 398.7 eV and 399.6, 398.2 eV were due to C–N and C=N, separately. Compare with MS and COF-TpTt, the two peaks of MS/TpTt (399.9 and 398.6 eV) shifted to lower and higher, respectively. Revealing the existence of charge transfer between MS and COF-TpTt and further indicating the interaction occurred between MS and COF-TpTt. For MTZIS-3 %, the C1s and N1s spectra were shifted to higher binding energy than that of MS/TpTt. Fig. 6c was the O 1s spectra, and the two peakes at 532.2 and 530.8 eV belong to O–H and C=O bonds in COF-TpTt, which were lower than that of MS/TpTt (533.0 and 531.5e V). And the C=O bond of MTZIS-3 % was shifted to lower binding energy (531.3 eV). Fig. 6d displayed the S 2p XPS spectra of ZIS, and the peaks at 162.7 and 161.5 eV correspond to S 2p1/2 and S 2p3/2 for S2− [47,48]. In the In 3d spectra (Fig. 6e), the two peaks at 451.4 and 443.8 eV correspond to In 3d3/2 and In 3d5/2 orbitals of In3+ [48], and the two peaks at 1044.8 and 1021.7 eV (Fig. 6f) matching to Zn 2p1/2 and Zn 2p3/2 derived from Zn2+, respectively [33,48]. Compared to ZIS, the S 2p spectra (166.7 and 163.2 eV), In 3d spectra (453.4 and 445.7 eV) and Zn 2p spectra (1045.8 and 1023.0 eV) of heterojunction MTZIS-3 % were all shifted to higher binding energy. The change in binding energy was closely related to the electron cloud density [34], and S 2p, In 3d and Zn 2p were all shifted to higher binding energy suggesting the electron cloud density of ZIS was decreased and the electrons transferred from ZIS to MS/TpTt. In addition, we have directly confirmed the interfacial charge dynamics under illumination by high-resolution in situ XPS techniques. Compared to MS/TpTt, the characteristic peaks of the C1s, N1s, and O1s spectra of MTZIS-3 % were shifted to lower binding energies in dark and shifted to higher binding energies in light (Fig. 7 a–c); whereas the two characteristic peaks of the S 2p, In 3d, and Zn 2p spectra of MTZIS-3 % were shifted to higher binding energies in dark and shifted to lower binding energies in light compared with ZIS (Fig. 7d–f). This result indicated that the photoexcited electrons transferred from MS/TpTt to ZIS, confirming the formation of S-scheme charge transfer pathway. The work function (Φ) of ZIS, MS/TpTt and MTZIS-3 % were calculated to further explore the interfacial charge transfer. The kinetic energy of free e− was impacted by the contact potential difference (ΔV) and ZIS and MS/TpTt have different Φ values, resulting in the binding energy changes of the e− [18,49,50]. The Φ values were computed using the equation: Φ = ΔV + φ, (ΔV values were derived from the spacing between the two inflection points (IP) by the VB-XPS plots (Fig. 8 a–c), φ was the work function of XPS analyzer and the value was 4.55 eV and the ΔV value of COF-TpTt was shown in Fig. S5). Thus, the Φ values of ZIS, MS/TpTt and MTZIS-3 % were calculated to be 5.72, 5.91 and 5.86 eV (5.23 eV for COF-TpTt), respectively. The Φ value of ZIS was smaller than that of MS/TpTt, while the EF of ZIS was greater than that of MS/TpTt (Fig. 7d). When ZIS and MS/TpTt were closely interacting (Fig. 8e), the electrons will transfer spontaneously from ZIS to MS/TpTt (this outcome was congruent with the XPS analysis) until the EF levels of the two reached equality. Hence, an internal electric field was formed in the direction from ZIS to MS/TpTt. Due to the loss and accumulation of electrons, the band edges of ZIS and MS/TpTt were bent upward and downward, respectively. Upon light irradiation, ZIS and MS/TpTt were aroused to produce e− /h+. Under the influence of internal electric field and Coulomb force, the holes on the VB band of ZIS recombined with the electrons on the CB band of MS/TpTt (Fig. 7f), retaining the electrons with high reducing capacity on the CB band of ZIS and the holes with high oxidizing capacity on the VB band of MS/TpTt, respectively. This result confirmed that the charge transfer mechanism of MTZIS-3 % during photocatalysis is S-scheme, which provided a strong guarantee for excellent photocatalytic performance. In addition, the work functions of the samples ZIS and COF-TpTt were calculated by density functional theory (DFT) (due to the complexity of the structure of the MS/TpTt and MTZIS-3 % composites, it was not possible to accurately simulate the crystal structure. Therefore, the DFT calculated figure of them could not be provided). As shown in Fig. 8g, the Φ value of In-S side was 3.65 eV and Zn-S side was 6.95 eV for ZIS. And the Φ value was 5.82 eV for COF-TpTt (Fig. 8h). The work function calculated by DFT was not much different from that calculated by the formula Φ = Δ V + ψ, indicating the relative accuracy of the work function calculated by the formula. 3.2 Electrochemical analysis Transient photocurrent response, electrochemical impedance (EIS) and photoluminescence (PL) were employed to analyze the charge separation and transfer process and kinetic events. The order of photocurrent intensity was MTZIS-3 % > COF-TpTt > MS/TpTt > ZIS > MS, indicating that the charge separation efficiency of MTZIS-3 % was the highest (Fig. 9 a). The order of EIS arc radius was MTZIS-3 % < COF-TpTt < MS/TpTt < ZIS < MS (Fig. 9b), suggesting the charge in MTZIS-3 % has the lowest resistance during transferring. The fluorescence was emitted upon recombination of photogenerated e− / h+, consequently, the intensity of PL was taked to reflect the extent of photogenerated e− / h+ recombination [49]. In Fig. 9c, the PL intensity of MTZIS-3 % was much lower than that of MS/TpTt, and the result showed that the doping of ZIS effectively promoted the charge separation and transfer of heterojunction MTZIS-3 %, which verified that the co-catalysis of ZIS inhibited the recombination of e−/h+ [51]. 3.3 Photocatalytic activity The photocatalytic performance of samples were measured via photocatalytic degradation of MO driven in visible light. The photocatalytic performance of ZIS, COF-TpTt and MS/TpTt were all lower than heterojunction MTZIS-x% (Fig. 10 a). Among them, MTZIS-3 % showed the best photocatalytic performance, and it could completely degraded MO in 60 min. Compared to MTZIS-3 %, the photocatalytic property of heterojunction TZIS-3 % without MS was obvious much weaker. The degradation curves of MO were fitted with first-order kinetics, which could be expressed as −ln(C t /C 0) = k × t, where C0, Ct, k denoted the initial concentration of MO, concentrations of MO at different degradation times and the kinetic rate constant, correspondingly. The k values of ZIS, COF-TpTt, MS/TpTt, MTZIS-1 %, MTZIS-3 %, TZIS-3 %, MTZIS-5 %, MTZIS-8 % and MTZIS-10 % were −0.0075, −0.0245, −0.0195, −0.0346, −0.0371, −0.0222, −0.0361, −0.0313 and −0.0280 min−1, separately (Fig. 10b). The k value of MTZIS-3 % was 4.95, 1.51, 1.90 and 1.67 times than that of ZIS, COF-TpTt, MS/TpTt and TZIS-3 %. Moreover, the MO degradation rate over MTZIS-3 % (100 %) was 1.54, 1.29, 1.32 and 1.28 times than that of ZIS (64.9 %), COF-TpTt (77.4 %), MS/TpTt (75.3 %) and TZIS-3 % (77.9 %), respectively (Fig. 10c). The result showed that heterojunction MTZIS-3 % has relatively excellent performance in photocatalytic degradation of MO. The total organic carbon (TOC) in the residual solution remaining after 60 min of degradation was determined by a TOC analyzer using an indirect method (TC-IC mode). The TC concentration was 62.63 mg L−1 and the IC concentration was 1.982 mg L−1. Thus, the TOC concentration was found to be 60.65 mg L−1. We hypothesized that this amount of TOC come from small molecule fragments in the degraded solution. We also studied the relationship between the different content of ZIS in heterojunction and the degradation efficiency. As shown in Fig. 10d, when the ZIS content was 3 %, the composite material has the highest degradation efficeency. Compared with previously reported similar photocatalysts, MTZIS-3 % showed superior capacity in degradation of MO (Table S3). Meanwhile, to obtain insight into the degradation process of MO over MTZIS-3 %, LC-MS analysis was performed (the detailed explain was added in Fig. S6). Furthermore, the stability of heterojunction MTZIS-3 % was tested by repeated photocatalytic degragration of MO under visible light. After recycling five times, due to the mass loss of MTZIS-3 %, its photocatalytic degradation efficiency was slightly decreased (Fig. 11 a). Nevertheless, the efficiency of MO degradation was still about 85 %. Meanwhile, the structure changes of MTZIS-3 % before and after cycling were recorded by the XRD patterns (Fig. 11b). The small structural changes before and after cycling indicated that heterojunction MTZIS-3 % still has strong stability. The decrease in degradation efficiency and minor structural changes after 5 cycles were attributed to the shedding of the catalyst loaded on the MS. 3.4 Photocatalytic hydrogen evolution The photocatalytic H2 evolution of samples were assessed using 30 mg catalyst in TEOA aqueous solution (0.5 % Pt) under 300 W Xenon lamp. In Fig. 12 a, MTZIS-3 % showed the best photocatalytic H2 generation activity (1382.84 µmol) within 4 h, and the corresponding photocatalytic H2 production rate was up to 11523.64 µmol g−1 h−1 (Fig. 12b), which were 7.02, 11.91 and 13.19 times than that of ZIS (1642.38 µmol g−1 h−1), MS/TpTt (967.54 µmol g−1 h−1) and COF-TpTt (873.65 µmol g−1 h−1), respectively. MTZIS-3 % has excellent photocatalytic hydrogen production performance, mainly due to the formation of S-scheme, which retains the high CB position of ZIS (CB = −1.15 eV), and the built-in electric field formed by the matched band structure effectively promotes the separation of electron-hole pairs. The apparent quantum yield (AQY) of MTZIS-3 % at different wavelengthse was assessed, which matched well with absorption ability (Fig. S7), and the AQY at 420 nm was 23.4 %. Moreover, after five times-cycle, the photocatalytic H2 yield rate of MTZIS-3 % was only reduced by 94.92 µmol g−1h−1 (Fig. 12c). Meanwhile, it can be observed that the SEM image as well as the characteristic peaks of FT-IR spectra and XRD pattern of MTZIS-3 % were not much changed after five cycles (Fig. S8). These results indicated that MTZIS-3 % has continuous and stable hydrogen production performance. Compared with previously reported ZnIn2S4-based photocatalysts, MTZIS-3 % in this study exhibited superior photocatalytic hydrogen production performance (Fig. 12d), and the comparative data are presented in Table S4. 3.5 Photocatalytic CO2 reduction The photocatalytic performance of CO2 reduction was evaluated in a mixed solution (H2O:MeCN:TEOA = 1:3:1) with 300 W Xenon lamp for 5 h. The results suggested the major product was CO, accompanied by a minor amount of H2. In Fig. 13 a, the total CO yield of MTZIS-3 % was 2507.75 µmol g−1, which was 2.68 times than that of ZIS (934.29 µmol g−1) and the selectively of CO2 was 96.17 %. Duo to the CB position of COF-TpTt and MS/TpTt were −0.31 and −0.51 eV, respectively, and cannot be photocatalyzed for CO2 reduction (CO/CO2 (−0.53 eV)) [52–54]. Obviously, MTZIS-3 % has the most high H2 yield (99.98 µmol g−1), and the H2 yield of ZIS, COF-TpTt and MS/TpTt were 8.05, 5.67 and 5.79 µmol g−1, respectively (Fig. 13b). The CO yield rate of MTZIS-3 % were 501.55 µmol g−1 h−1 and the H2 yield rate was 19.99 µmol g−1 h−1, which were all higher than that of ZIS, COF-TpTt and MS/TpTt (Fig. 13c). Fig. S9 showed the CO production of MTZIS-3 % under different conditions, and the results showed that no CO was produced without CO2, no photocatalyst and no light, which proved that the source of CO was the photocatalytic reduction of CO2. Compared with reported heterojunctions, MTZIS-3 % has excellent photocatalytic CO2 reduction performance (Table S5). Considering practical applications, the stability of photocatalytic CO2 reduction of MTZIS-3 % was also researched for five cycles (Fig. 13d), and no significant changes for CO and H2 production were observed, indicating the good stability of MTZIS-3 %. 3.6 Photocatalytic mechanism It was very important to study the photocatalytic mechanism to further understanding the photocatalytic degradation process. Thus, we investigated the production of active species in heterojunction MTZIS-3 % photocatalytic system by adding various trapping agents during the photocatalytic process. MeOH, CCl4, NBT, IPA, CAT and Carotene act as scavengers of h+, e−, ·O 2 – , ·OH, H2O2 and 1O2, respectively. We separately studied the effect of varied quantities of capture agent on the photocatalytic activity (Fig. S10). When adding trapping agents of 1 mL CCl4, 1.5 mL MeOH, 50 µL IPA, 2 mL NBT, 50 µL CAT and 2 mg Carotene, respectively, the photocatalystic activiry was more inhibited (Fig. 14 a). The corresponding photocatalytic degradation efficiencies were 89.4 %, 86.1 %, 83.1 %, 79.7 %, 91.1 % and 94.6 %, respectively (Fig. 14b). The results indicated that e−, h+, ·OH, ·O2 –, H2O2 and 1O2 were all active species involved in the photocatalytic degradation reaction. Among them, e−, h+, ·OH, ·O2 – have stronger effect on the photocatalytic degradation system than H2O2 and 1O2, and the influence order of active species were ·O 2 – > ·OH > h+ > e− > H2O2 > 1O2. To explore the molecular oxygen activation capacity of the above reactive oxygen species (ROS), TMB oxidation tests were conducted with the addition of various quenchers under visible light. Herein, IPA, CAT, NBT and Carotene were used to remove ·OH, H2O2, ·O 2 – and 1O2, respectively. Fig. S11 showed the change in the absorption peak intensity of the TMB oxidation products over the time. ZIS exhibited very weaker TMB oxidation capacity and MTZIS-3 % has the strongest TMB oxidation capacity, which was 162.1 and 1.93 times for ZIS and MS/TpTt, respectively (Fig. 14c). Furthermore, the molecular oxygen activation capacity of MTZIS-3 % was inhibited when scavengers were added (Fig. 14d). Obviously, IPA, CAT, NBT and Carotene could all inhibited TMB oxidation, whereas NBT and Carotene inhibited TMB oxidation more than IPA and CAT, suggesting ·O 2 – and 1O2 were the most dominant ROS in TMB oxidation reaction. The electron spin resonance (ESR) technique was taked to further detect the above ROS production. Their generation were highly influenced by electronic band structure of photocatalyst [55]. In Fig. 15 a–d, no ESR signal peak was generated in dark condition. However, the ESR signal peaks of DMPO-·OH, DMPO-·O 2 – , DMPO-H2O2 and TEMP-1O2 appeared under visible light irradiation and the signal peaks of ESR were enhanced by extending the time to 10 min. The ESR signal peaks of ·OH and ·O 2 – were very strong, indicating high redox-active electrons and holes in the heterojunction MTZIS-3 %. There were characteristic signal peaks of H2O2 and 1O2 in the system, which we considered to be the results that ·O 2 – reaction with H+ and h+. The above results proved that ·OH, ·O 2 – , H2O2 and 1O2 were important ROS in this photocatalytic reaction system, and ·O 2 – was the most dominant ROS. Considering the above results and analysis, we put forward a rational S-scheme charge transfer mechanism with high redox activity (Scheme 2 ). ZIS and MS/TpTt were aroused to produce e− and h+ when lighting. Based to the S-scheme charge transfer mechanism, under the effect of internal electric field, band bending and Coulomb force, the e− on the CB of ZIS recombined with the h+ on the VB of MS/TpTt, thus the e− with high reduction activity on the CB of MS/TpTt and the h+ with high oxidation activity on the VB of ZIS were retained. e− reduced O2 to H2O and ·O2 –, and ·O2 – further reacted with H+ to form H2O2 and then form ·OH. Meanwhile, h+ oxidized H2O, OH– and ·O2 – to O2, ·OH and 1O2. The detailed reaction process were as follows: MS/TpTt/ZIS + hν → [MS/TpTt (e−+ h+) + ZIS (e−+ h+)](2) O2 + e− → ·O2 –(3) O2 + e− → H2O2(4) ·O2 – + e− + 2H+ → H2O2(5) H2O2 + e− → OH– +·OH(6) 2H2O + 4 h+ → O2 + 4H+(7) OH– + h+ → ·OH(8) ·O2 – + h+ → 1O2(9) (e−, ·O2 –, ·OH, h+, 1O2, H2O2) + Pollutant → Products (CO2 + H2O + others)(10) 3.7 Biotoxicity testing Residual organic pollutants and biotoxicity in the solution after photocatalytic degradation have become a widespread focus for practical applications. In this study, the biotoxicity of MO in solution before and after photocatalytic degradation were evaluated via observing the germination of mung bean in different solutions. Mung beans of the same variety and size were placed in 3 petri dishes of the same size with different medium and cultured for 7 days with distilled water (Fig. 16 a), MO solution after photocatalytic degradation (Fig. 16b) and MO solution (Fig. 16c), respectively. Obviously, mung beans cultured in distilled water all germinated and root growth was vigorous. Surprisingly, mung beans cultured with photocatalytically degraded MO solution also germinated normally and grew well. Compared to mung beans cultured in distilled water, the slower germination of mung beans cultured in the degradation solution within 7 days was due to the presence of degraded debris molecules. However, mung beans cultured with MO solution for 7 days only sent a little bud, mung beans skin was stained yellow by the MO solution, and the growth condition was very poor. The result showed that MO was almost completely photocatalytic degraded by MTZIS-3 % and the biotoxicity of the degraded MO solution was essentially eliminated. The photocatalytic degradation of MO solution could be used in real life applications (planting, watering, etc). 4 Conclusion In conclusion, we successfully synthesized a novel heterojunction MTZIS with melamine sponge foam (MS) as the carrier by solvothermal method. Among all the samples, MTZIS-3 % showed excellent photocatalytic performance and higher stability under visible light, which could completely degradated MO (30 mg/L of 50 mL) in 60 min. Moreover, the H2 generation rate of MTZIS-3 % could reach 11523.64 µmol g−1 h−1. And the CO yield rate of MTZIS-3 % was up to 501.55 µmol g−1 h−1. Furthermore, the TMB oxidation result showed that MTZIS-3 % also has a superior molecular oxygen activation ability. The charge transfer mechanism in heterojunction MTZIS was revealed by work function calculations, and proposed the rational S-scheme charge transfer mechanism. The highly efficient photocatalytic performance was ascribed to: (i) the formation of S-scheme enhanced the charge efficient separation and transfer, (ii) the negative CB position of ZIS makes the heterojunction photocatalyst MTZIS-3 % with a higher reduction activity, (iii) the sponge structure of the large skeleton and the nitrogen-rich structure of MS/TpTt enhanced the light absorption and utilization. Meanwhile, biotoxicity study has shown that MTZIS-3 % was valuable for practical applications in photocatalysis. coredata.dc:description: Charge separation critical for improving photocatalytic performance. But single semiconductor cannot realize efficient charge separation and transport. Little research has been reported on using melamine foam (MS) as a carrier. Herein, we have successfully synthesized a heterojunction MS/TpTt/ZnIn2S4-x% (MTZIS-x%) photocatalysis with MS as the carrier by solvothermal method. It was found the degradation rate of MO over MTZIS-3 % could reach almost 100 %, and the biotoxicity tests showed that degraded residual liquid of MO was almost non-biological toxicity. Moreover, the ptotocatalytic H2 evolution rate of MTZIS-3 % reached to 11523.64 µmol g−1h−1, which was 7.02, 11.91 and 13.19 times than that of ZIS, MS/TpTt and COF-TpTt. And the evolution rate of photoreduction CO2 to CO was 501.55 µmol g−1 h−1. The excellent photocatalytic property was owing to the S-scheme band structure facilitated the separation of electron-hole efficiently and retained the highly reducing electrons. This work provided a theoretical reference for the construction of efficient new heterojunction photocatalysts using MS as a carrier.

coredata.dc:title: Construction of visible light-driven ternary S-scheme melamine sponge MS/TpTt/ZIS heterojunction photocatalysts for enhanced photocatalytic pollutant removal and hydrogen evolution
